The best economic period in history was the 1950s and 1960s which the tea 
party says is their goal to return the USA to. The middle class was the

made that such a great time. A family could thrive with the husband working 
a blue collar job while the wife stayed home to raise the children. They 
could afford to buy a home, a car, take a vacation every year and save for 
their kids college and their daughter's wedding as well as retirement.

But how was it possible? Because of socialism. Yes that is factually

comments.text:
+Dinner with Mariah But your entire historical premise on why the U. S. 
manufacturing economy boomed in the 50's is a fiction. American workers 
didn't do so well in the 50's because there was some magic in the air, much 
less because of socialism. You are putting the cart before the horse. The 
reason they did so well was because so much of the manufacturing capacity 
of the West had been blown all to hell in this little skirmish called WWII. 
The reason the U. S. was doing so well was because we had the only game in 
town. Capital goes where it is treated best, and that was here. The only 
large, stable, functioning manufacturing base left was ours, so we could 
afford to pay our people most - there was no competition, and moving 
overseas at the time was foolish. And our relative economic strength 
declined, not because of the Koch brothers or the evils of capitalism, or 
because we dropped the tax rates from 90%, but because the rest of the 
world developed quickly and was able to compete again. Tax revenues 
actually increased when the rates were dropped from 90%. And not because of 
some trickle down foolishness, but because what rational person is going to 
increase their workload to only get 10% of their pay? If you worked for a 
rate of $100/hour at a tax 35% rate, but when you hit 40 hours a week that 
tax rate went to 90%, would you work extra? For a take home of $10? Hell 
no! 
What did result from that wealthy time was corporate complacency, which has 
hurt us. The reason companies like Toyota and Honda were able to suddenly 
compete with and at times surpass U. S. car companies was because many 
companies here never stopped to notice that the world had changed, and they 
weren't changing with it. Japanese companies developed many new operation 
and management ideas that allowed them to blow past us. Heard of "just in 
time" manufacturing, or "kiazen," or lean manufacturing? Japanese ideas 
after WWII, much of it pioneered at Toyota.  
Finally, did you know that we now manufacture more in the U. S. than we 
ever have before? Despite all the companies going overseas, all the 
supposed tax breaks they get for going, despite the higher wages that our 
workers demand, we make more stuff here than ever. Do you know why that 
hasn't translated into more jobs? Automation. Unless you plan on smashing 
up machines like some neo-Luddite, those jobs are just gone. Machines do 
them better, cheaper, and faster. 
You can't put that egg back together again. Unless you are expecting a 
large portion of the world's manufacturing capacity to be blown to bits, 
and yet again we come out unscathed, it's a pipe dream. The 50's and 60's 
are long gone, and dreamy socialism isn't going to bring it back. 
Read some history, take some business, tax, and econ classes.
comments.author: TheTubbsfox

+Stock Market Guru Pt. 1 -- Yes, that's exactly correct. I'm a real estate

were heavily regulated. In the States that wasn't the case. There were many 
documented cases in America where predatory agents and lenders would 
knowingly defraud people, making them believe they could qualify for 
mortgages that they should not have been approved for. Oftentimes they were 
immigrants who weren't very comfortable with English and couldn't 
understand the paperwork. Have you ever seen and agreement of purchase and 
sale for a home? They're wordy and full of legalese that, if not familiar 
with them, can be very difficult to understand. What the predatory lenders 
did is set the interest rate artificially low, making the initial first few 
months of payments affordable, but buried in the document was a "balloon 
rate." After a few months the interest rate would "balloon" up to the 
actual rate, which would mean that the home buyer now couldn't afford 
his/her mortgage payments. Thus, they would go into default. These 
mortgages were insured by the government so it was a WIN WIN for everyone 
except the person who bought the home.

have a government that protects us from corporations, and doesn't give them 
our stolen money, then you might have a good argument for not voting 
libertarian. but as it is right now, government spends more of our money 
fucking us over than it spends helping us out, and it will probably always 
be that way until we abolish the government entirely or start using it the 
way it was meant to be used. i don't think rand paul is the best choice but 
we don't exactly have many other options. if we're only going to just pick 
the lesser of two evils, we might as well just start a revolution. if we 
can't settle things democratically, and we haven't been able to for 
decades, what makes you think this problem is going to change? every 
generation has thought "let's not settle this with a violent revolution. 
let's wait, it will eventually get better." and then they died. and then we 
came along, and went through the same experience, and waited just like they 
did. we keep waiting and waiting, and then forgetting how long we've been 
waiting because a new generation has replaced the old one. we don't have 
our parents' memory. we were born into this shit and we expect it to change 
eventually. but it hasn't changed and it won't change if we keep waiting 
until we're dead. if we could live long enough we'd see that it's not gonna 
change, but just as we realize that we need to revolt, we die and a new 
generation comes along to do more waiting. this is how it keeps going, it's 
just the cycle of exploitation. black slaves were probably the same way. 
waiting to be freed, then dying, then waiting to be freed, then dying, and 
so on. eventually they were freed but this is just way too profitable, and 
way too easy for the elites. it will not go away unless we fight back, and 
we're not going to fight back if we keep waiting. either teach your 
children that this problem has been going on for a long time, and if the 
problem doesn't go away when they're young, they need to fight back... or 
fight back yourself. but there is just no excuse for putting your kids 
through the same abusive "democracy" that you were born into, and letting 
them wait and wait the same way you did.

comments.text:
+BartJ583 Sorry, but I disagree with your point of "there is no THEY". 
 "They" IS the government.  Warren is part of them (the worst part of 
them).  I do agree that "we" have to change and that change can only come 
by not sending these idiots back term after term when they are NOT doing 
what we sent them to do.  There should NEVER be a term called "career 
politician".  There should never be someone in congress or the senate more 
than two terms.  This in my opinion is why are country is in the shit hole 
it is.  The only people now that we should be voting for are those that 
will promise to vote for term limits.  Until that happens, NOTHING will 
change.  Once they get there and see the amount of power they get, then 
they don't want to leave.  So what they begin doing is in their own 
interests and not ours.  We as voters can actually do the term limit thing 
ourselves.  All we have to do is decide NOT to vote for them any longer 
after a second term in office and vote a challenger into office.  This 
would stop their bullshit antics and actually start making them do what 
they are sent there to do.  I would love to see a movement begin of a vast 
number of voters pledging to not vote for the same candidate more than 
twice.  This in essence would be our way of imposing term limits on these 
power hungry clowns.  This would also encourage people to run who are only 
interested in making things better for the country than those only running 
to make a career for themselves in politics.
